review.title: Discrete Elastic Inner Vector Spaces with Application in Time Series and Sequence Mining
review.abstract: This paper proposes a framework dedicated to the construction of what we call discrete elastic inner product allowing one to embed sets of non-uniformly sampled multivariate time series or sequences of varying lengths into inner product space structures. This framework is based on a recursive definition that covers the case of multiple embedded time elastic dimensions. We prove that such inner products exist in our general framework and show how a simple instance of this inner product class operates on some prospective applications, while generalizing the Euclidean inner product. Classification experimentations on time series and symbolic sequences datasets demonstrate the benefits that we can expect by embedding time series or sequences into elastic inner spaces rather than into classical Euclidean spaces. These experiments show good accuracy when compared to the euclidean distance or even dynamic programming algorithms while maintaining a linear algorithmic complexity at exploitation stage, although a quadratic indexing phase beforehand is required.

metadata.title: Discrete Elastic Inner Vector Spaces with Application to Time Series and Sequence Mining

sections.text: ar Xiv: 120 6.61 96v1 [cs.LG] 2 7Ju n20 12Index Terms - Vector space, discrete time series, Sequence Mining, Inuniform sampling, Elastic inner product, Time verping.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: T IME series analysis in metric spaces has attracted much attention over numerous decades and in various fields such as biology, statistics, sociology, networking, signal processing, etc., essentially due to the ubiquitous nature of time series, whether they are symbolic or numerical. Among other characterization tools, time delay distances (see [20], [13], and more recently [7], [9] among other references) have shown some interesting robustness compared to the Euclidean metric, especially when similarity search in time series databases is a problem. Unfortunately, this type of elastic distance does not allow the direct construction of certain cores that are useful when it comes to regression, classification or clustering of time series. A fortiori, they do not make it possible to directly construct inner products that include some time elasticity, which are essentially able to cope with some strains or a compression along specific dimensions.

sections.heading: 2 ELASTIC INNER PRODUCT VECTOR SPACES
sections.text: Based on the recursive structure of the Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) equation, in which the non-linear max operator is replaced by a sum operator, we propose a fairly general and parameterized recursive equation, which we call an elastic product. Our goal in this section is to derive the conditions under which such an elastic product is an internal product that maintains a form of time elasticity.

sections.heading: 2.1 Sequence and sequence element
sections.text: Definition 2.1. Faced with a finite sequence A, we use A (i) to denote the ith element (symbol or example) of sequence A. We will consider that A (i) and S (S) represent a vector space in which the multi-dimensional space variables (e.g. S-Rd with d-N +) and T-R embed the timestamp variables, so that we can write A (i) = (a (i), ta (i)))) in which a (i), S and ta (i), T, with the condition that ta (i) > ta (j) whenever i > j (timestamps increase strictly in the sequence of samples). Aji with i ≤ j is the sub-sequence that consists of the ith through the jth element (including) of A. So A j i = A (i + 1)... A (j).

sections.heading: 2.2 Sequence set
sections.text: Definition 2.2. The set of all finite discrete time series is thus embedded in space-time, which is characterized by a single discrete temporal dimension encoding the timestamps, and any number of spatial dimensions encoding the value of the time series at a given timestamp. We note U = {Ap1 | p, N} the set of all finite discrete time series. Ap1 is a time series with a discrete index that oscillates between 1 and p. We note the empty sequence (with zero length) and, by convention A01 = BA, so that it is a member of the set U. | A | denotes the length of the sequence A. Let us = {A, U | ≤ p} be the set of sequences whose length is shorter or equal to p. Finally, let us let U ² be the set of discrete time series defined on (S − {0S}) × T, i.e. the time series that do not contain a spatial value.

sections.heading: 2.7 Algorithmic complexity
sections.text: The general complexity associated with calculating the eip of two time series of lengths p and q according to Equation 2 is O (p · q), which is basically the same complexity as calculating complete dynamic programming solutions such as the Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) [20] [13] algorithm evaluated on the basis of these two time series. Nevertheless, Prop. 3.2, as discussed in Section 3.3, enables efficient implementations of the retrieval process (in linear time complexity) once a simple indexing phase has been implemented, which is demonstrated in practice in the experimental stage (paragraph 4).

sections.heading: 3 SOME PRELIMINARY APPLICATIONS
sections.text: In the following sections, we present some applications to highlight the properties of Elastic Inner Product Vector Spaces (EIPV S).

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Orthogonalization of an independent family of time series with increasing lengths
sections.text: The family of time series we are looking at consists of 11 uniformly recorded time series, the length of which is 11 samples: (1, 0) (1, 1 / 10) (1, 1, 0) (1, 1 / 10) · · (1, 1 / 10) (1, 1 / 10) (1, 2 / 10) · · · (1, 1) (4) Since the zero value cannot be used for the spatial dimension, we have replaced it with the smallest non-zero positive reality for our test machine (i.e. 2 − 1074).The result of the Gram Schmidt orthogonization process using ν =.01 on this basis is given in Fig.2.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Orthogonalization of a sine-cosine basis
sections.text: An orthonorthonormal family of discrete sine cosine functions is no longer orthogonal in an EIPV S. The result of the Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process with ν =.01 when applied on a discrete sine cosine basis is shown in Fig.3, in which only the first 8 components are shown, and the length of the waves is 128 samples.

sections.heading: 3.3 Indexing for fast retrieval in time series data bases
4 EXPERIMENTATIONS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Meta parameters
sections.text: In order to investigate the potential advantages of an elastic inner product against the inner product of Euclidean, we have also tested the Euclidean distance, which, however, as already mentioned, is the limit if the SVM classifiers take advantage of the potential advantages of an elastic inner product against the inner product. The cores evaluated by the SVM classifiers are the Gaussian nuclei Keip (A, B) = e − δeip (A, B) 2 / (2 · 2) and Ked (A, B) = e − 3, 2 ·, 2 ·, 2. The meta parameters C are selected from the discrete group {2 − 8, 2 − 7,...

sections.heading: 4.2 Sequence classification
sections.text: We report here on a protein classification experiment conducted using the Protein Classification Benchmark Collection (PCBC). [1] This benchmark contains structural and functional annotations of proteins. The two datasets we exploited, SCOP95 and CATH95, are available at http: / / hydra.icgeb.trieste.it / benchmark; the entries of the SCOP95 datasets are characterized by sequences of variable length and relatively low sequence similarity (less than 95% sequence identity) between protein families. The CATH95 dataset contains nearly identical protein families of different lengths in which the proteins exhibit high sequence similarity (more than 95% sequence similarity).

sections.heading: 4.3 Experimental complexity
sections.text: In order to evaluate the calculation costs of δeip in practice, we compare it with two other distances, δed (the Euclidean distance), which has a linear complexity, and δdtw, the Dynamic Time Distortion, which has a square complexity. Additionally, we evaluate the calculation costs of the indexed version of δeip, which we call δi − eip. The experiment consists in generating random datasets of 100 time series of increasing length (10, 100, 1000 and 10000 samples) and calculating the 100x100 distance matrices. Figure 7 indicates the elapsed time in seconds, according to a logarithmic scale, for the four distances as a function of the length of the time series. Compared to δeip, δeip is very efficiently evaluated on the basis of the matrix calculation given in the equation, although without any offline indexing of the time series, δeip does not compete with the length of the line, which is clearly compared to the one that is compared to the ilined line in a curve.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: This work has made it possible to embed such time series in a single inner space, for example in the area of numerical or symbolic sequences.

We report here a protein classification experiment carried out using the Protein Classification Benchmark Collection (PCBC) [18] [1].
• BLAST [2]: the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool is a very popular family of fast heuristic search methods used for finding similar regions between two or more nucleotides or amino acids.
• SW [17]: The SmithWaterman algorithm is used for performing local sequence alignment, for determining similar regions between two nucleotide or protein sequences.
• NW [11]: The Needleman Wunsch algorithm performs a maximal global alignment of two strings.
• LA kernel [12]: The Local Alignment kernel is used
• PRIDE [5]: The PRIDE score is estimated as the PRobability of IDEntity between two protein 3D

The PRIDE method [5] gets the best results, but it uses the tertiary structure of the proteins while all the other methods exploit the primary structure.

metadata.abstractText: This paper proposes a framework dedicated to the construction of what we call discrete elastic inner product allowing one to embed sets of non-uniformly sampled multivariate time series or sequences of varying lengths into inner product space structures. This framework is based on a recursive definition that covers the case of multiple embedded time elastic dimensions. We prove that such inner products exist in our general framework and show how a simple instance of this inner product class operates on some prospective applications, while generalizing the Euclidean inner product. Classification experimentations on time series and symbolic sequences datasets demonstrate the benefits that we can expect by embedding time series or sequences into elastic inner spaces rather than into classical Euclidean spaces. These experiments show good accuracy when compared to the euclidean distance or even dynamic programming algorithms while maintaining a linear algorithmic complexity at exploitation stage, although a quadratic indexing phase beforehand is required.
